The average-the-percentages-of-days-in-bracket model (percentage overall and percentage in last 30 days, intended to combine trend with reversion to mean), gives 80.75% (↑) for 30-40% and 19.25% (↓) for 41-49%. When making your projection, remember to account for the ±3 margin of error (and the fact that that itself is only a 95% confidence interval) on the Gallup poll.
At 37% on July 30th and trending South.

At 37% on 30 & 31 July (3-day averages), down from 39%, 38% on 28 & 29 July respectively. Strongly suggests 1-day numbers for 30 & 31 July on the low end, rendering 3-day average on 1 August very unlikely to rise above 40%.

37% on 30 July. 
It would need to go up 4 points by 01 August i.e. in 2 days, which happened twice in April, but not since then. There's always that 3% margin of error to consider too.
Closer to the date gives it less chance
There's never been a jump from 37% to over 40% in recent weeks. This is too close for comfort with the margin of error, but even +3% leaves him at 40% inclusive.

Updating from 0/90/10/0/0. The ratings for 28,29,30 July were 39%, 38%, 37% respectively [1]. Since the numbers reported by Gallup are 3-day rolling averages, this suggests that the "true", 1-day approval on 30 July was quite low, around 35% according to my calculations (it's impossible to know for sure though). Moreover, the approval reported for 1 August will be the 3-day average of 30 July, 31 July, and 1 August. The 30 July number being so low cuts down the chances of this average being high. [1] http://www.gallup.com/poll/201617/gallup-daily-trump-job-approval.aspx
It's about safe to call it sub 40%

As this administration continues to alienate the majority, it also seems to pressure its own party. 
Whether this is intentional, in the sense that it's a calculated strategy to force his party to adopting the views he wishes because it is how it worked for his business ventures OR one which there is a failure to understand the difference in public service and big business- who knows? 
I'd say short of a crisis, approval ratings will continue to fall. 
However, with that being said, it does seem the perfect time for a manufactured fear driven opportunity. 
That's actually my biggest concern.
As is his wont, Trump is making this hard on us by hovering just below 40%.

I underestimated how much negative attention Trump was capable of creating for himself. I also thought it was possible for people to forget him briefly. I was wrong. Updating to 30-40 inclusive all-in.

Based on current numbers 30-40 range is most probable despite pretty wild news cycles numbers are consistently in that range. There is a not unsubstantial risk that the investigation or into Russia or Trumps reaction to the investigation could cause talk of impeachment by the already frustrated senate (health care failures and Trumps statements making things hard for them). As a reaction to building frustration senators may leak investigation details or use breaking news as a final straw. If they begin talking about impeachment and pressuring the house to begin proceedings Fox will begin to turn as well and approval ratings will drop to about 28%. 
Alternatively Trump could possibly say something that rallies and inspires righteous anger in conservative against opponents. Alternatively, if budget arguments begin ahead of what is expected (health care battle quickly abandoned) this could unite the republicans and give a boost in morale and a spike in aprooval ratings.  Final and unlikely possibility is that straight repeal of ACA could pass. While highly unlikely it is also probably the trickiest to predict the impact of. There would likely be a temporary boost in aprooval followed by a large drop if the likely gridlock on a replacement ensues.

http://www.gallup.com/opinion/polling-matters/214100/things-trump-people-perspective.aspx?utm_source=alert&utm_medium=email&utm_content=morelink&utm_campaign=syndication "A recent Washington Post piece included this quote: "What remains remarkable about the past six months is how durable the president's support has been among Republicans. Despite objectively losing almost every news cycle since he took office, Trump's approval rating among GOP voters is still at the same level in Gallup's tracking polls as George H.W. Bush and Ronald Reagan at this point in their presidencies." "While Trump receives high ratings among Republicans, as the Post notes, he gets extremely low, single-digit approval ratings from Democrats and only about one-third approval from independents. That accounts for his historically low overall approval ratings among newly elected presidents in the summer of their first year. . . .  "Trump's support has been stable. There has been little meaningful change since March, with his weekly averages ranging narrowly between 37% and 42%. This stability may result at least partly from the increased polarization . . . with both Republicans and Democrats firmly entrenched in their opinions.
. . .
" . . .  About two-thirds of those who disapprove of Trump talk about his character, personal qualities and overall qualifications as their reasons for holding those attitudes. . . .  Approvers tend to talk about Trump's presidency more generally or mention issues.
. . . 
"One important fact about Trump is the degree to which some of his positions on the issues actually resonate with the public -- including spending a great deal of money on the nation's infrastructure, trying to bring manufacturing jobs back from overseas, helping veterans and creating more jobs in general. In fact, our new data show that Trump gets higher ratings for his stance on issues than for having the personality and qualities expected of a president. . . . Something for people to keep in mind -- the Gallup poll has a sampling-based margin of error of ±3.  So if you think there is, in fact, a 100% chance that he'll have 38.00% support in the population on August 1st, you still should (assuming you're trying to match your prediction to that belief) allocate significant probability that error means it'll be reported at a 41% (within the 95% confidence level) or even 42+% (the 2.5% chance the poll is out of the confidence interval high).  If you're declaring 100% to between-30-and-40, you're predicting, more-or-less, that his actual support will be 34-36%.  (If I could remember more of my long-ago statistics classes, I could give you more precise advice, but it's been far too long.) Now, the model I use, operating directly on the frequency of given numbers in the Gallup reporting instead of a belief as to what Trump's underlying support is, should minimize avoid sampling uncertainties; all historical slop from sampling error is included.  (Did Trump's June 22 42% reflect reality or error?  My model doesn't care, it just cares with what frequency Trump gets a 41+.)  Its major deficiency -- and it IS a major one -- is that by dealing with those numbers directly, it is only indirectly linked to the underlying reality.  It's like trying to predict a stock's price based on the past performance of a stock, without any direct looks at the fundamentals or a study of market psychology or, well, anything.  My acknowledgment of that inherent uncertainty is the 1%s I spend on either side of the main prediction; whether it's adequate, excessive, or insufficient is, of course, hard to evaluate. Had to eliminate <30%: Trump base is about 35% and is solid: Trump will not go down below 30% even when he's impeeched. Also had to eliminate the other extreme of >60% approval. The Democrat base isn't going anywhere and it is about 40%. Had to put 0% for 50-60%: the never-Trumpers are still strong (evidence in the GA 6th district and SC special election), and Trump did not win the popular vote.
Now the hard part: how much to put in the 30-40 bracket and how much in the 40-50 bracket. Starting with 100% in the 30-40 bracket (current position), what would nudge the poll up to 40-50 bracket?
1. The economy: even though it is improving at fast pace, it won't have enough time to change opinions.
2. His agenda: mostly pleasing his base and may convert some republicans/independents to his supporters column, but the two main items (repeal of Obamacare and tax reform) may not see the light before August 1 and even by then, won't sway opinions much.
3. His reaction toward external threat (such as 9/11 or invasion of Kuwait kind of magnitude): this may make unpopular president popular. But such event is rare and we won't have enough time to see it happen.
4. Statistical margin of error: +/-3% margin of error for Gallup polls. For example, if true approval rate were 38%, a poll may, by statistical fluke, read it as 41%, putting it in the 40% bracket. With a gently downward trend, I would put the chance of above 40% to about 10%.

I wanted to do a primarily quantitative analysis first without taking into account Trump's extremely unorthodox characteristics as a president.  I used historical Gallop approval rating data since 1993 when Clinton was inaugurated to analyze how quickly approval ratings change.  Besides cases when a new president is inaugurated and the ratings apply to a different person, there was only one case where an extremely fast change occurred - the poll after 9-11 when George Bush's ratings improvement from 51 to 87%, including 27 to 82% for Democrats.  That case was considered an outlier - the table below shows the month to month deltas for percentage approval.  For the one month deltas, 90% were between a change of -6% and 5% change, and for the two month deltas, 90% were between -7% and 6% change. Since there are two months until this period and the rating is very close to 40% right now, I find it highly unlikely there will be more than a 10% change before August 1st (roughly 4% of historical cases have this much of a jump in either direction).  Due to Trump's loss of "strong approval" ratings have shrunk roughly 9% since he became president and his "strong disapproval" ratings have risen roughly 10%, I feel it more likely that he will suffer a decrease in approval in the next two months than an increase.  (See FiveThirtyEight https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/donald-trumps-base-is-shrinking/ for more information.)
I also find it very likely he'll be within 5% of his current approval of roughly 40%, but it is difficult to assign probabilities to demonstrate that with the brackets that are provided.  As a result, I will assign a higher probability to him falling below 40% than rising above.  If it were possible, I would assign much higher (~80%) that he'd be within 35-45% than outside of that range.

While presidents before Clinton have enjoyed approval ratings above 60%, such high numbers have been very rare with presidents for the past 20 years. Hence, it is unlikely that Trump will be able to beat those numbers since there haven't been many major changes in American politics since Clinton. (H. W. Bush also never picked up his approval numbers again during his exit.) H. Bush enjoyed high approval ratings mainly because of his response to the 9/11 attacks. For Trump to have such a high approval rating, there would need to be a major event like 9/11. But 9/11 was completely unprecedented in American history because of the enormous scale of the attack on civilian lives. Even with the rise of ISIS, it is unlikely that a similar attack will occur because of increased American security since 9/11. Perhaps there might a crisis with North Korea that might lead to a spike in Trump's approval ratings. However, Kim Jong Un hasn't done anything spectacularly different since his inception. Kim Jon Un's actions have been roughly the same as his actions when Obama was in office. Thus, the two major international issues that might increase Trump's approval rating are unlikely to occur. The only other possibility that might increase Trump's approval rating is the economy. Although the economy did fairly well under Clinton, Clinton still did not spend much time with above 60% ratings during his presidency. That only happened in the last two years of his presidency, not the last two years. Furthermore, this requires that Trump's economic policies will have a positive effect on the economy. But given that a lot of the disgruntlement about the economy from the working middle class (the base of Trump's supporters) is about the lack of jobs, it is unlikely that Trump's current policies will change much. For the past 20 years, a lot of American manufacturing jobs have been lost to automation and other technological advances. These advances will continue to happen and they will continue to disrupt traditional American jobs. Even with Obama's stimulus packages delivered right to those middle-class workers, Obama did not spend much time with approval ratings greater than 60%. Finally, and most importantly, presidents since Clinton (w/ exception of H. Bush during 9/11) have had quite steady approval ratings. Since his approval ratings is at around low 40's and high 30's according to five-thirty, it is likely that the numbers will stay there, with some downward trajectory. For all the reasons, I have listed, it is unlikely for Trump's approval ratings to go up. Although they may go down, they would only go down with a scandal like Watergate. In all the Gallup polls, American presidents have had approval ratings above 30%. Carter, for all his flaws, only spent a brief period of time below 30%. Even then, his low ratings were at the end of his presidency, not the beginning. Nixon was the only president in American history to resign. For Trump to follow in that footsteps, he would have to have a scandal on the magnitude of Watergate. Even then, Watergate took almost 2 years to play out. Other scandals like the Iran-Contra scandal and Clinton's Lewinsky scandal also did not do much to presidents' approval ratings. While there is a probability of things going badly for Trump, especially with Comey's upcoming testimony, that probability is low.

Prospects are fading for US President Donald Trump to get a big boost at home from his first foreign trip as two new polls show his approval rating stagnating or declining and doubts rising about his credibility.
Fifty-four percent of voters say Trump is abusing the powers of his office, according to the latest survey by Quinnipiac. Only 37 percent approve of his job performance, about the same as the 36 percent who approved two weeks ago. Fifty-nine percent say Trump is dishonest.
Sixty-six percent support the appointment of a special counsel to investigate possible improper links between the 2016 Trump campaign and Russia. Trump opposed that investigation, but the Justice Department named former FBI Director Robert Mueller as special counsel anyway.
"President Donald Trump remains mired in dreadful mid-30s approval numbers and the red flags that are popping up tell an even darker story," Tim Malloy, the poll's assistant director, told reporters. "But by far the most alarming determination is that President Trump is abusing his office."

COMMENTS:  Trump supporters, however, may not read those news, and probably do not care a fig on how bad his performance was while abroad.  Gallup has his rating at 42 today; but: His approval rating is even worse than most people realize: While it fluctuates daily, Trump’s Gallup approval rating has hovered around 40 percent for most of his time in office. Making him the “president” with the lowest approval rating at this point in their presidency in modern history. For comparison’s sake, here’s Barack Obama and George W. Bush’s final approval ratings:
* Obama: 59 percent
* Bush: 34 percent
With an economy that’s just as strong as it was when Barack Obama left in January with a 59 percent approval rating, Trump’s number sits much closer to Bush’s, who left office in the midst of the worst economic crash since the Great Depression.
If the economy falters, even a little, all things being what they are now (aka his unhinged behavior remaining what we’ve seen thus far), Trump could reach never-before-seen levels of Americans who disapprove of the job he’s doing as “Commander-in-Chief.”
So while an approval rating are between 35-40 percent is never good, seeing as it’s this early into his administration, and the economy is still strong, Trump’s numbers are actually worse than they appear. He spends several hours practically every morning obsessing over cable news: Despite what Trump thought going into this, being president is extremely difficult. It’s a non-stop grind where you’re never truly “off the clock.”
However, despite the fact that presidents have a never-ending list of things to which they need to attend, it seems as if Trump spends several hours nearly every morning obsessing over what cable news morning shows are saying about him.
Looking at Trump’s Twitter rants, they mostly occur in the morning, around the same time most cable news networks are airing their morning shows such as Morning Joe, Fox & Friends, and New Day.
Some have even pointed out how Trump’s tweets often mirror things he clearly just heard on his favorite morning show, Fox & Friends.
This is how obsessed he is with what people are saying about him. To say nothing about the fact that a person with practically unlimited power to get whatever information he wants still seems to rely heavily on being “informed” — by cable news.

The past month median for Trump's approval rating has been 40 (41 for his term so far). His approval rating has not been very volatile, but previous presidents in the past have experienced large swings in approval over a short time (e.g. Bush following 9/11). Even absent large swings, drifts of 10 percentage points or more over the course of a few months are far from unheard of. For example, Obama's approval rating fell about 10 percentage points from late May 2009 to the end of July.  On the other hand, it's relatively rare for a president's approval rating to fall below 30%, and this seems particularly true in today's politically polarized times. Even amidst all of the negative press surrounding the Trump administration's dealings with Russia, his approval rating remains in the high 30s.

 - DT's policy initiatives - the budget, the health care bill - will hurt many.

A widely held tenet of the current conventional wisdom is that while President Trump might not be popular overall, he has a high floor on his support. Trump’s sizable and enthusiastic base — perhaps 35 to 40 percent of the country — won’t abandon him any time soon, the theory goes, and they don’t necessarily care about some of the controversies that the “mainstream media” treats as game-changing developments. It’s an entirely reasonable theory. We live in a highly partisan epoch, and voters are usually loyal to politicians from their party. Trump endured a lot of turbulence in the general election but stuck it out to win the Electoral College. The media doesn’t always guess right about which stories will resonate with voters. But the theory isn’t supported by the evidence. To the contrary, Trump’s base seems to be eroding. There’s been a considerable decline in the number of Americans who strongly approve of Trump, from a peak of around 30 percent in February to just 21 or 22 percent of the electorate now. (The decline in Trump’s strong approval ratings is larger than the overall decline in his approval ratings, in fact.) Far from having unconditional love from his base, Trump has already lost almost a third of his strong support. And voters who strongly disapprove of Trump outnumber those who strongly approve of him by about a 2-to-1 ratio, which could presage an “enthusiasm gap” that works against Trump at the midterms. The data suggests, in particular, that the GOP’s initial attempt (and failure) in March to pass its unpopular health care bill may have cost Trump with his core supporters.

Looking at both Gallup's data and 538's poll averaging/forecasting for Trump, there is a clear negative trend month-to-month for approval polling, though Gallup's numbers are a bit less stable in trajectory. Using just Gallup's average change in approval for Trump every 30 days so far, I would find that from day 1 to day 194 (Aug 1) there would be a drop of ~11.5% in approval, for a rating of 33.5%. Intuitively I find something similar to this to be the most likely - Trump is already down close to his core support group for these approval ratings, and it would be hard to definitively shake tons of support from them OR for him to make a large turnaround. However, polls thus far haven't really captured potential fallout from the Comey/Flynn revelations of the past week so things may go further underwater for him soon.  A swing to put Trump below 30% would need to be large and sustained - something like multiple big news items in the next two-ish months. Not impossible, but these would need to be items that shook even diehard supporters. There is potential for this with recent Russia investigation updates. On the flip side, a jump of 15-25 points in that time would need to convince a lot of people that Trump is doing a good job. Only certain kinds of events can do this in a short time (e.g., a magic bipartisan tax plan?, terrorist attack?) and so I find this unlikely.  Because of the trends in his approval going generally downward and the fact that disapproval has been going UP more consistently, I think there could be the most reason to expect him to end up in the sub-40 range around August 1st. I'm still conflicted on this vs. 40-50%, though.

This drop in predictions is primarily driven by what happened on May 9th: the firing of Comey. The closest historical analogue I could think of is the Saturday Night Massacre, so I quickly estimated the overall drop in approval ratings, and it looks to be a 3-4% drop from right before the massacre to my approximation of the 81 day time frame. I was at first estimating the drop was going to be around 2.4%, and then I changed my estimation to about a 6.4% drop, taking into account the fact that President Obama dropped about 13% over the time frame, and now that I looked at it, that was the closest analogue. Now that this has happened, and if I adjust for another 3% down, we're looking at the final approval rating being roughly around 36-35%. 
Some other things that could change: 
-The AHCA becomes law. I'm actually pessimistic about this, because if you look at the day the AHCA passed the house, approval ratings actually dropped by 2%. As such, if this becomes law, I'm looking at roughly another 3% drop. 
-Something big happens in the investigation with Russia. I don't think this is going to happen, but if something does happen, I'm thinking it'll be at least 5%, maybe 10%. But I doubt something is going to happen, even with the accelerated pace that is likely to occur due to the hubbub around Comey. Regardless, I adjusted my lower ratings probabilities up a little.

This is my first forecast, so I don't really know how to play, but basically I took the average drop/gain in approval ratings as best as I could estimate for the 193 day time-frame for all of the Presidents that Gallup has (goes back to Truman) and then applied that here. As best as I could calculate (there was some guesstimation because numbers didnt' neatly line up), it is a drop of -2.44% from the inauguration. 
Some issues I still have to work on: the standard deviation on this is really high. As such, in a little bit, I'm going to redo my estimates based on two metrics: a) nearest neighbor, where i'll roughly guess the closest historical analogue for which I have poll data based on what we've seen so far, and then b) which is an events based model, in which I'll figure out what causes the polls to change broadly, and then I'll edit more particularly later. If anything significant happens (big law signed, Russia investigations go poorly, etc.) I'll modify up or down based on the data I get from (b). 
As mentioned, this is my first forecast, so I have no idea what I'm doing. Any constructive criticism will be appreciated.

OK, we got another question of this kind to play with. @Anneinak, please note that the resolution rules are clearly defined and imply that the rating FOR August 1 will be the decisive one :). But then the proper wording would be  "..FOR August 1". So what do I foresee for the next 94 days? 
 - The tax discussion would be a small net negative for DT from here, as the positive effect is already consumed and people can only get disappointed when more specifics come. 
 - Health care could be either a second debacle (if the Republicans try and fail again) or a small positive (if anything passes). 
 - Military action/posturing anywhere would be a small positive. 
 - The Russia investigation would be a small negative (if more news about "coordination" emerges) or a net zero (if nothing new happens). (It would be a positive if it is completed without implicating DT's campaign, but I don't think it will finish by Aug 1). 
 - DT's chest-thumping on trade issues is a small positive for him, keeps the base happy.  
 - And the twitting habit has subsided, which keeps everyone happy.  However, all presidents lose ground from their starting point, although DT seems an exception so far - he started low, but have not lost much (Jan 22 approval rating: 45%; Apr 28: 43%). All in all, I see him in the low 40s (more likely) or high 30s.

It will be extremely difficult for Trump to crack the Democratic base and garner support from them. Assuming he can get his administration to demonstrate a more traditional form of governance, he can bring his numbers above 50%. If he can't, and the administration follows the same haphazard method of governance, he'll likely maintain in the 40-50% range or decrease slightly below 40%. Above 60% and below 30% are highly unlikely, unless something amazing/catastrophic happens. As we approach August, we'll be able to better assess his progress or lack thereof.
